options.text: His use of stress and poetic meter

multiple-choice.question: What is a foot in poetry?

options.label: A
options.text: A unit of stressed and unstressed syllables

multiple-choice.question: What is iambic pentameter?

options.label: A
options.text: A meter where each line consists of five one-syllable iambs

options.label: B
options.text: A meter where each line consists of five two-syllable iambs

options.label: C
options.text: A meter where each line consists of three one-syllable iambs

options.label: D
options.text: A meter where each line consists of three two-syllable iambs

multiple-choice.question: What is an iamb?

options.label: A
options.text: A stressed syllable followed by an unstressed syllable

options.label: B
options.text: An unstressed syllable followed by a stressed syllable

options.label: C
options.text: A unit of three syllables with the first stressed and the second and third unstressed

options.label: D
options.text: A unit of two syllables with the first unstressed and the second stressed

multiple-choice.question: Why do Shakespeare's characters often switch to iambic pentameter when expressing emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's a complex and difficult meter to use

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's a natural and expressive way to convey emotions

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's a way to show off their poetic skills

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's a way to sound more formal

multiple-choice.question: What is the natural rhythm of the human heartbeat, according to the text?

options.label: B
options.text: Da duhm, da duhm, da duhm, da duhm, da duhm

options.label: D
options.text: Da duhm da duhm da duhm

multiple-choice.question: Why is iambic pentameter believed to be naturally suited to the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's a complex and difficult meter to use

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's a meter that follows the natural rhythm of the human heartbeat

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's a meter that is easy to memorize and understand

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's a meter that is commonly used in English poetry

multiple-choice.question: What is a dactyl?

options.label: A
options.text: A unit of three syllables with the first stressed and the second and third unstressed

options.label: B
options.text: A unit of two syllables with the first unstressed and the second stressed

options.label: C
options.text: A unit of one syllable with the first stressed

options.label: D
options.text: A unit of four syllables with the first unstressed and the second stressed

multiple-choice.question: What is a trochee?

options.label: A
options.text: A unit of two syllables with the first stressed and the second unstressed

options.label: B
options.text: A unit of two syllables with the first unstressed and the second stressed

options.label: C
options.text: A unit of three syllables with the first stressed and the second and third unstressed

options.label: D
options.text: A unit of four syllables with the first unstressed and the second stressed

multiple-choice.question: Why do Shakespeare's characters often use iambic pentameter when speaking about their emotions and place in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's a way to show off their poetic skills

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's a way to sound more formal

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's a natural and expressive way to convey emotions

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's a way to confuse their audience

title: Why do buildings fall in earthquakes? - Vicki V. May

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of building collapse during an earthquake?

options.label: B
options.text: The displacement of the foundation and lower levels

multiple-choice.question: What two main factors determine the strength of a building's oscillation during an earthquake?

options.label: B
options.text: The building's stiffness and material type

options.label: D
options.text: The building's height and column shape

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves matches the natural frequency of the building?
What is the effect of increasing a building's mass on its natural frequency?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the rate of vibration

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases the rate of vibration

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the rate of vibration

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of base isolation in building design?

options.label: C
options.text: To absorb shocks and limit deformation

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of tuned mass damper systems in building design?

options.label: C
options.text: To cancel out resonance by oscillating out of phase

multiple-choice.question: Which type of buildings are more susceptible to damage from low-frequency earthquake motions?

options.label: C
options.text: Buildings with a low natural frequency

options.label: D
options.text: Buildings with a high natural frequency

multiple-choice.question: Which type of buildings are more susceptible to damage from high-frequency earthquake motions?

options.label: C
options.text: Buildings with a low natural frequency

options.label: D
options.text: Buildings with a high natural frequency

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of engineers working with geologists and seismologists to predict the frequency of earthquake motions at building sites?
What is the key to preventing building collapse during an earthquake?

title: Why the Arctic is climate change's canary in the coal mine - William Chapman

multiple-choice.question: What is the Arctic region described as in terms of its role in predicting the impact of climate change?
What type of surfaces are very effective at reflecting the sun's energy back into space?

options.label: B
options.text: White surfaces like snow and ice

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the Arctic warms and some of the snow and ice melts?

options.label: A
options.text: The ground and ocean underneath cool down

options.label: B
options.text: The ground and ocean underneath warm up and cause more melting

options.label: C
options.text: The air above the Arctic cools down

options.label: D
options.text: The air above the Arctic stays the same

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of Arctic sea ice in the climate system?

options.label: A
options.text: To absorb heat from the ocean

options.label: B
options.text: To release heat from the ocean

options.label: C
options.text: To act as a buffer between the frigid arctic air and the relatively warmer water underneath

options.label: D
options.text: To block sunlight from reaching the ocean

multiple-choice.question: What type of feedback loop is caused by the release of moisture into the atmosphere when ice melts?
Why is the negative feedback loop caused by the release of moisture into the atmosphere short-lived?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is caused by the brief Arctic summers

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is caused by the long Arctic winters

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is caused by the cold temperatures in the Arctic

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is caused by the warm temperatures in the Arctic

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential consequence of the recently increased impact of positive feedbacks in the Arctic?

options.label: A
options.text: A slower warming rate at the North Pole compared to the equator

options.label: B
options.text: A faster warming rate at the North Pole compared to the equator

options.label: C
options.text: No change in the warming rate at the North Pole

options.label: D
options.text: A cooling of the Arctic region

multiple-choice.question: How may the reduced temperature differences between the North Pole and the equator affect weather patterns in the middle latitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: It may lead to faster jet stream winds and more linear atmospheric circulation

options.label: B
options.text: It may lead to slower jet stream winds and less linear atmospheric circulation

options.label: C
options.text: It may have no effect on weather patterns in the middle latitudes

options.label: D
options.text: It may lead to more extreme weather events in the middle latitudes

multiple-choice.question: What may be the consequences of shifts in weather patterns in the middle latitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: Short-term fluctuations may become persistent cold snaps, heat waves, droughts, and floods

options.label: B
options.text: Short-term fluctuations may become less extreme

options.label: C
options.text: Short-term fluctuations may become more frequent

options.label: D
options.text: Short-term fluctuations may become less frequent

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to study the Arctic region in terms of its potential impact on climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a remote and inaccessible region

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a complex and finely balanced natural system

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a sensitive indicator of climate change

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a large and populous region

title: McDonald's Cup Sizes Around The World

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall equation for photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: 6 CO2 + 6 H2O + light energy â†’ C6H12O6 (glucose) + 3 O2

options.label: B
options.text: 6 CO2 + 6 H2O + light energy â†’ C6H12O6 (glucose) + 6 O2

options.label: C
options.text: 3 CO2 + 3 H2O + light energy â†’ C6H12O6 (glucose) + 6 O2

options.label: D
options.text: 6 CO2 + 6 H2O + light energy â†’ C6H12O6 (glucose) + 3 H2O

multiple-choice.question: Where do the light-dependent reactions occur in a plant cell?

options.label: B
options.text: In the thylakoid membranes of chloroplasts

multiple-choice.question: What is the byproduct of the light-dependent reactions in photosynthesis?
What is the light-independent reaction in photosynthesis?
What is the primary function of chlorophyll in photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: To absorb light energy and convert it into ATP

options.label: B
options.text: To absorb light energy and convert it into glucose

options.label: C
options.text: To absorb CO2 and release O2

options.label: D
options.text: To absorb H2O and release glucose

multiple-choice.question: What is the optimal temperature range for photosynthesis?
What is the effect of increasing CO2 concentration on the rate of photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases the rate of photosynthesis

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the rate of photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the rate of photosynthesis

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases the rate of photosynthesis at high temperatures

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the stroma in photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the site of the light-dependent reaction

options.label: B
options.text: It is the site of the light-independent reaction

options.label: C
options.text: It is the site of the electron transport chain

options.label: D
options.text: It is the site of the light reactions

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall purpose of photosynthesis?

options.label: D
options.text: To produce light energy and heat

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of photosynthesis for life on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces light energy and heat

title: The great conspiracy against Julius Caesar - Kathryn Tempest

multiple-choice.question: Who led the conspiracy to assassinate Julius Caesar?

options.label: A
options.text: Senator Gaius Cassius Longinus and his friend and brother-in-law, Brutus

options.label: C
options.text: Julius Caesar's rival, Pompey the Great

multiple-choice.question: How many times was Julius Caesar stabbed by the conspirators?
What was the result of the power vacuum that followed Caesar's assassination?

options.label: A
options.text: The Roman Republic continued to thrive

options.label: B
options.text: The concentration of power under the office of Emperor

options.label: C
options.text: The end of the Roman Empire

options.label: D
options.text: The rise of a new dynasty

multiple-choice.question: Who delivered a passionate speech at Caesar's funeral?
Why did Brutus join the conspiracy to assassinate Caesar?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a loyal friend of Caesar

options.label: B
options.text: He was motivated by a desire for power and wealth

options.label: C
options.text: He feared Caesar's growing power and the threat it posed to the Roman Republic

options.label: D
options.text: He was forced to join by Cassius

multiple-choice.question: What was the legacy of Brutus after his death?

options.label: A
options.text: He was viewed as a selfless fighter against dictatorship

options.label: B
options.text: He was viewed as an opportunistic traitor

options.label: C
options.text: He was viewed as a neutral figure

multiple-choice.question: What was the Roman Republic's principle that was threatened by Caesar's growing power?

options.label: A
options.text: The concentration of power under the office of Emperor

options.label: B
options.text: The checks and balances between the different branches of government

options.label: C
options.text: The end of the Roman Empire

options.label: D
options.text: The rise of a new dynasty

multiple-choice.question: Who was the leader of the conspirators who underestimated Caesar's popularity among the Roman public?
What was the result of the series of civil wars that followed Caesar's assassination?

options.label: A
options.text: The Roman Republic continued to thrive

options.label: B
options.text: The concentration of power under the office of Emperor

options.label: C
options.text: The end of the Roman Empire

options.label: D
options.text: The rise of a new dynasty

multiple-choice.question: What question remains relevant today, over 2,000 years after the assassination of Julius Caesar?

options.label: B
options.text: The conflict between personal loyalties and universal ideals

title: How do the lungs work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the respiratory system?

options.label: B
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells and clear the system of carbon dioxide

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the system that controls the vital functions of the body, including breathing?
What is the name of the muscle that flattens when the body prepares to take in oxygen-rich air?
What is the name of the tiny air passages that lead to the air sacks in the lungs?
What is the name of the process by which oxygen and carbon dioxide are exchanged in the lungs?
What is the name of the protein that grabs oxygen in the bloodstream?
How many times does the respiratory system inhale and exhale per minute?
What is the approximate amount of air that the respiratory system inhales and exhales per day?
What is the name of the system that causes the diaphragm to ball up and the intercostal muscles to relax during exhalation?
What is the name of the tiny air sacks in the lungs where the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide occurs?
